loans.name: Kamuli B3(I) Group

texts.en:
This group has been together for one year. Rose is 45 years old. Currently she sells used clothes. With the extra business profits, she wants to construct a permanent residential house. Sauda and Harriet both sell new clothes and want to use the loan to increase stock. Daphine has a beauty salon and wants to use the loan to buy hair dryers.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: These women would like to invest in their businesses.

loans.name: Kadiba South A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Fredali N.. She is currently in the business of running a bar and is requesting a loan to purchase more furniture and beer. Fredali is 38 years old and is married. Her husband trades in coffee. She has 2 children aged 2 and 5 and her children go to school. Each week, Fredali makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to educate her children and add to her business. Fredali has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 400000 in order to add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Fredali is joined in her small group by Rebecca N., Mary T., Aidah N., and Sarah N.. Rebecca N. has a hair dressing business and wants to add to the business. Mary T. is currently operating a retail shop business and wants a loan to purchase more shop items. Aidah N. operates a garment shop business and wants to boost business. Sarah N. is currently in the business of tailoring and is requesting a loan to buy more clothing materials.

loans.use: To add to bar business

loans.name: Delia Luz

texts.es:
Señora Delia belongs to the community bank Santa Bárbara, located in the jewelry section of Market No. 2, of the district of Calleria in the province of Ucayali. She is 42 years old and a mother of two children. Her husband is employed by Essalud, but the income that he has does not meet the family's economic needs. With the first loan that she received through Manuela Ramos for 300 Soles, she decided to invest it in the sales of fine jewelries.

Presently she has a position where she sells jewelry. She opens her stand very early in the morning and serves there until four in the afternoon. After that she is dedicated to her house and the care of her children.

With this loan of 3000 Soles, which she will pay back in five months, she will invest in buying jewels, earrings, rings, necklaces, bracelets, watches, etc. Delia is very content working in her business since she can offer economic wellbeing to her family.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva volunteer

La señora Delia pertenece al Banco Comunal Santa Bárbara, ubicado en el Mercado No 2 Sección joyería, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 42 años y es madre de 2 hijos, su esposo es empleado de Essalud, pero los ingresos económicos que tiene no le alcanzan para su economía familiar, Con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos S/. 300 decide invertirlo en la venta de fantasías finas.

En la actualidad ella cuenta con un puesto donde vende sus joyas, abre su puesto muy temprano y atiende hasta 4 pm, luego se dedica a su hogar y cuidado de sus hijos.

Con este préstamo de S/. 3,000 el cual será pagado en 5 meses, invertirá en la compra de joyas, aretes, anillos, pendientes para mujeres, cadenas, esclavas, relojes, etc. Delia esta muy contenta trabajando en su negocio le puede brindar el bienestar económico a su familia.

loans.use: purchase more products to sell in her business

loans.name: Run

texts.en: Mrs. Run R. earns about $7.33 per day purchasing rice to resell. R. is a 40-year-old widow and lives with her two childR. in Run Choeung village, Siem Reap province. She requests a loan of $1,200 to purchase rice to resell. The remainder of the loan will be used to purchase small pigs. This investment will increase her family’s income.

loans.use: To purchase rice to resell

loans.name: Aloema

texts.en:
Aloema F., 25 years old, is married with four children. Aloema has developed over three years of business experience selling vegetables, taro and bananas. She sells to people from her village and the general public, and she earns approximately 200 Tala (~83 USD) per week.

Aloema has received three previous loans from SPBD. SPBD loans are Aloema’s only access to capital because she was unable to qualify for loans from traditional banks. She will use her loan to purchase fertilizer, chemicals, pesticides, a shovel, a rake, taro tubers, and a weed killer. Her husband and children will do the farming.

loans.use: To purchase farm equipment

loans.name: Saturdina

texts.es:
Saturdina is a very enterprising woman. She works long hours each day including getting up very early to feed her animals and take them out of their pens. Along with her husband she then sews olluco, potato, onions and broad beans. They both wish to continue with their labours as they really want to improve the quality of life of their family and contribute to the development of their much loved kids.

Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

Saturdina, es una mujer muy empeñosa, trabaja diariamente desde altas horas de la mañana para sacar a sus animales y pastarlos en la amplitud de la pradera, mientras se alimentan junto a su esposo se dedica a cultivar la tierra y siembran olluco, papa, habas y cebada. Desean continuar con esta labor debido a que tiene muchos deseos de contribuir con el mejoramiento de su calidad de vida familiar y el desarrollo de sus amados hijos.

loans.use: An injection of capital to improve earnings/Inyección de capital para mejorar sus actividades.

loans.name: Juan

texts.es:
Juan is a loving father who responsibly cares for his household. Since he was a child his parents taught him the true value of work and the dignity it brings to one's life. This is why he is diligently prospering with his small clothing shop of jackets, backpacks and handbags, merchandise which they transport and sell in the city of Cuzco. In this manner Juan continues to get ahead together with his three young employees to whom he is able to offer secure jobs. This diligent man and his dear wife would like to expand their shop in order to make it one of the biggest in the area. They are sure that with your helping hand their dream will come true in no time!

Translated from Spanish by Kristy Placido, a Kiva volunteer.

Juan es un amoroso padre que toma las riendas de su hogar muy responsablemente, desde niño sus padres le enseñaron el verdadero valor del trabajo y cuan dignificante es en la vida de una persona, por ello, que diligentemente viene prosperando con su pequeño taller de confección de casacas, mochilas y maletines, mercadería que transportan y venden en la ciudad del Cuzco, de esta forma Juan viene saliendo adelante y junto a sus 3 jóvenes empleados a quienes les ofrece un trabajo seguro.Este diligente hombre y su querida esposa tienen en mente ampliar su taller hasta convertirlo en uno de los más grandes de su localidad, están seguros que con tu mano amiga podrán cristalizar en corto tiempo este gran anhelo.

loans.use:
Raise investment capital for the expansion of his clothing shop.

Incremento de capital de inversión para la ampliación de su taller de confecciones.

loans.name: Say

texts.en:
Say S., age 28, is married and lives with her husband in Prey Veng, Cambodia. Since 2006, she has been selling a variety of groceries to earn a living and is able to earn up to US$5 of profit per day. Her husband, age 30, has a business running a motor-taxi to help support his family and is able to earn up to US$3 of profit each day. Both of them were farmers before starting these businesses, but had to change their work because of bad weather conditions. In their village, there is no irrigation system so their family and other villagers depend on the weather to farm.  They are all very happy when there are dark clouds, but if there is no rain their crops or rice are damaged. Every month, this couple needs to pay around US$75 for food, US$10 for utilities, and US$50 for their children's education.

Mrs. Say S. is seeking a loan of US$600 to add to her grocery inventory to meet her customers' demands. (Mrs. S.'s mother is pictured because Mrs. Say S. and her husband were not available.)

CREDIT MFI is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor and small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services.

loans.use: To add inventory to her grocery business in order to meet her customers' demands.

loans.name: Fred Ato

texts.en: Since 1994, Fred Ato M. has been selling ice blocks and operating a pepper-milling machine in Elmina. Fred Ato has received tertiary education. He is married and has 2 children. His wife is a trader. He is responsible for paying his children's school fees, providing food for the family, and paying the utility bills. He plans to use the loan to buy spare parts for his milling machine. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to reinvest and expand the business.

loans.use: Buy spare parts for pepper-milling machine

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther H. is a member of the community bank Marcela. Ester, 28, lives with her partner and their 2 children aged 8 and 11. In the small town of Ayacucho, where Esther lives, she provides a very important service by renting small moto-taxis. The moto-taxis are a great way to get around the city. She also sells groceries from the rainforest. Esther travels every week to the rainforest to gather groceries. She spends 4 days a week in the rainforest and 3 days in Ayacucho and Lima selling her goods. 

She will invest her loan in the purchase of corn, sugar, vegetable stew and on bus tickets for travel. For her future, she dreams of having a bigger moto-taxi renting business; she is interested in also purchasing a truck to help with hauling her goods from the rainforest.

loans.use: To purchase corn, sugar, vegetable stew and on bus tickets for travel.

loans.name: Anonymous Group

texts.en:
Sopheap C. is 22-years-old and is a mother of two children who are two and four years old. She is married to Chhit Ka, who is a palm juice collector. Sopheap is the village bank president of a bank loan which consists of fifteen people, located in the Andoung Russey Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is also a pot maker in the local village. Her husband needs new equipment for his business, and is requesting a loan to buy additional materials to produce more palm sugar.
This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Four members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To request a loan to buy bamboo to tie with palm three in order to climb up the palm three to gather juice.

loans.name: Savun

texts.en:
Mrs. Savun N., 25, and her husband married in early 2008. She has four siblings and lives with her parents, brothers and sister on an Island of Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.
 
Savun has been a silk weaver, a skill she learned from her aunt, since she was sixteen years old. Besides weaving, she also has started to buy silk fabric from her fellow villagers for resale in another province. Her husband is a mason. 

Savun is requesting a loan of 300 to purchase silk fabric for resale and buy fertilizer for her father growing rice.

loans.use: To purchase silk fabric for resale and buy fertilizer for her father growing rice.

loans.name: Kaniz Fatima Group

texts.en:
Kaniz Fatima baji is a 54-year-old widow and resides in an area called Kot Radha Kishan which is 24 km from the town of Kasur, Pakistan. She has been living in this town for the past 10 years. She is the mother of five kids: four sons and one daughter. Her eldest son repairs sewing machines. The next one works in a factory. The third son works in a musical group as a drummer. Her youngest son works in a gas station. Her daughter stays at home and does household work. Kaniz baji is a midwife with experience gained over the past 12 years. She is applying for a loan to buy tools for her son so that he will be able to repair sewing machines easily and earn a good profit.

Kaniz Fatima baji is the group leader for several more women. Safia baji wants a loan to buy mason's tools. Abida baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk-selling business. Suraiya baji wants a loan to buy thread to re-sell. Seema baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for carrying loads. Irshad baji wants a loan to buy steel utensils to sell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy tools for repairing sewing machines

loans.name: Seik

texts.en:
Mrs. Seik S. is a villager in Phnom Sruoch village in Kampong Cham province. She is a pig breeder. Since her pigs have grown bigger and bigger, she does not have enough money to buy pig feed for them. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. Her husband, Mr. Kang Misae, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice.

Mrs. Seik S. is a 23-year-old mother of two children who are too young to work or study. Her husband and her children are presented with her in the picture.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy pig feed for her growing pigs.

loans.name: Yahaya

texts.en:
Yahaya A. is an entrepreneur in Tanzania. He is married and he runs a bakery at Makangarawe ward in Dar es Salaam. He bakes loaf bread and cakes of different sizes and designs. He has both wholesale and retail customers. He has been in the business for six years. 

Yahaya wants to expand his production but he lacks the funds to do so, so he is requesting a loan of TSH 1,200,000 ($925 USD) to expand his business.

loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Realonda

texts.en:
Realonda C. assists her husband through the buying and selling of dressed chicken parts. She buys and sells every 15th day of the month payable within 15 days. For their daily consumption, her husband works as a personal driver every day. 

Her two children are both studying. But it is not easy for the kids to study because they don't have electricity connection. Through the previous received HSPFI microfinance loan they were able to have electricity installed. Her dream is to let her children finish their studies. To materialize this dream, she wants to apply for a loan amounting to PHP15,000 to finance her business.

loans.use: purchased  dressed chicken for her buy and sell business.

loans.name: Tarek

texts.en:
Tarek is a 26 year old man who lives in Saida, southern Lebanon. He sells and repairs mobile phones and phone accessories.

He requests a loan of $1500 from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his shop. This is the first time Tarek has requested a loan.

Tarek is speciA. because he sells all kind of mobile phones and knows how to treat his clients. His clients can be anybody. When Tarek first started his business, he didn’t have the start up capitA.. He decided on doing this business because of his experience in the field. In the future, he plans on improving his business.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for his shop.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria has owned a small food-vendor store in the Kihesa neighborhood of Iringa for 10 years and she is local alcohol seller. She belongs to Semtema "a" East group loan (Group code 2024). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $125. Every day she works at her business for seven hours.

Victoria is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can increase her current stock for the expansion of her business. She is hoping that, through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Victoria is 47 years old, married, and has two children: ages 20 and 19. She also cares for seven additional dependents.

loans.use: To increase current stock to expand her business

loans.name: Swalia C Edranigo Zaida Group

texts.en: Zaida E. is a 35-year-old married mother of six children, four boys and two girls, all attending school except for the youngest. She also has four other dependents. Zaida has been operating her hotel restaurant for over 20 years, selling food specifically for breakfast, lunch, and dinner  and is now requesting a loan to purchase items such as wheat flour, bananas, cassava flour, cooking oil, charcoal and other items for the business. She is progressing well and her standard of living is improving. Her dream is to open a big hotel, buy a plot of land and build a house.

loans.use: To purchase hotel restaurant items such as wheat flour, bananas, cassava flour, cooking oil, charcoal and other items.

loans.name: Gaudencia

texts.en:
Gaudencia  D. is from the village of TURNO. She is 34 years old. Gaudencia is married and has one infant child. To make a living, Gaudencia owns & operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for her business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Gaudencia has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Gaudencia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gaudencia has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Gaudencia is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Gaudencia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Hatam

texts.en: Hatam (his relative is pictured) was born in 1964. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of the Azerbaijan Fuzuli town, now settled in Horadiz town. He is married and has 2 children. He has been in the business of fruit and vegetable sales for 7 years. Now he needs a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy fruits and vegetables for improving his business.

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Radhika

texts.en:
Mrs. Radhika B. is a tailor in the village of Bhakepati in Kathmandu district. She opened her tailoring shop 5 years ago. Her specialty is making custom-fitted ladies dresses like Kurta Sulwar, Blouse, Ladies long dress, Makhshi, and others.

Before starting her own business, Mrs. B. took a 6 month training course in tailoring near her town. Her husband died a few years ago and now she has sole responsibility for her daughter.

She plans to use the loan of Rs 20,000.00 to buy raw materials for her tailoring work. Her economic condition is very low to fulfil the basic needs for her family, so she needs a loan to expand her business to earn more profit to fulfil her family's basic needs.

She lives with her father-in-law, mother-in-law and one daughter. Her father-in-law is a farmer and her daughter is studying in pre-primary school.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her tailoring work

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: growing cocoyams

loans.name: Monica's Group

texts.en:
A. Monica is the leader of the Rwempiri subgroup in Ibanda. She is a 26 year old, friendly, and the mother of two children. She also cares for her parents deep in the village.

Monica has been in the business of selling shoes from Kashonda, Kazo for eight years and she is able to make profits worth 80,000 UGX. She is grateful for the loans because they make it possible for her to have quality shoes in her stock. Also, she would like to expand into a larger business with increased stock. With the loan, Monica hopes to buy more stock to avoid shortages.

Monica prays that her children continue being healthy so that the savings she makes will cater for their school fees once they start school.

loans.use: To buy more shoes to increase her stock

loans.name: Benson

texts.en:
Benson M. is 35-years-old and married with two children. He stays in Kiwanja near the University where he operates his business. This is a rural-urban set up and his customers are mainly students the University. He has been in business for the last 4 years.

He has borrowed funds from another Microfinance but was later on introduced to KADET by a friend. Benson is involved in various activities, like photocopying, printing services and he is also operating an MPESA(money transfer) Business on the side.

He intends to buy two more computers so that he can diversify his services to the students. His future long term plans include getting into the real estate business to secure his financial stability.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services in order to  relieve suffering and improve living conditions in communities across Kenya.

loans.use: Buying  two more computers

loans.name: Lidya

texts.en:
Lidya is a member of the Majengo borrower group in Kiboriloni, Kilimanjaro. She is 38 year old woman, She is married and a mother of 1 child. Her child is 19 year old.

Lidya has owned a  saloon business for 12 years. She works 8 hours a day and earns a monthly profit approximately 50,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Lidya`s second loan from BRAC_Tanzania. She requested the amount of 250,000 Tsh in order to buy more saloon goods like shampoo.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Lidya hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more goods for saloon

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en: Daisy G. is a 54-year-old woman from Tala, Caloocan City. Her husband, Benjamin, 55, works for a construction firm. Two of their ten children are in school. The eldest is already working. Daisy has a general store in front of their house. In the afternoon, she sets up a table in front of her store to sell balut and barbecue (a balot or balut is a fertilized duck (or chicken) egg with a nearly-developed embryo inside that is boiled and eaten in the shell). She makes P1,500 everyday doing this. She has been enjoying her business for the last ten years. Daisy joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2006 upon the invitation of a friend. She is now on her 8th loan. She needs additional capital for the expansion of her business so she applied for a new loan of P12,000. Daisy hopes to own a grocery store someday. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To use as additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Ena

texts.es:
Ena tiene 33 años, vive con su pareja, quien es albañil, y con sus 5 hijos que son estudiantes. Desde hace 13 años tiene un negocio de venta de bebidas y postres en su propia casa, debido a que frente a su vivienda hay un pequeño parque donde concurren muchos jóvenes a practicar deporte y es ahí donde aprovecha en vender sus bebidas. Sin embargo, por las mañanas también se dedica a la venta de golosinas y frutas afuera de un jardín de niños, siendo éstos y los profesores sus principales clientes. Lo que a Ena le gusta de su trabajo es vender y dar una buena atención a sus clientes, por lo que para más adelante quiere llegar a tener un local donde venda refrescos y helados.
Con MFP ya tiene 8 créditos y lo que le gusta de trabajar con su banco comunal  es que todos los integrantes son personas cumplidas en sus pagos y coordinados cuando trabajan juntos. El dinero que ahora solicita lo invertirá en la compra bebidas heladas, golosinas y frutas.
texts.en:
Ena is 33 years old. She lives with her partner, who works as a bricklayer, and their 5 school-aged children. For 13 years, she has been selling soft drinks and desserts from her home. In front of her house is a small park where many young people play sports, so Ena is able to sell them drinks. However, in the mornings, she also sells candy and fruit outside of a kindergarten where the teachers are her main customers. What Ena enjoys most about her job is selling her products and providing good service to her customers. In order to get ahead, she would like to open a shop where she can sell refreshments and ice cream.

Ena already has 8 previous loans with MFP. She enjoys working with her Communal Bank and is satisfied that all the members have completed their payments and work well together. The money she is requesting will be used to buy cold drinks, candy, and fruit.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase cold drinks, candy, and fruit

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en: Lydia is a farmer from Agusan Del Sur. She plants rice on her farm. She is 55 years old, married, and has 8 children. Her farming business helps her family expenses and also supports her children’s education. She wants to expand her farm so she could help improve her family’s living condition. Lydia applied for a loan from CEVI for Php12, 000. She will use this loan to finance her farm and hopefully expanding her business.

loans.use: Farm Financing

loans.name: Tegemea A.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 27-year-old Tegemea M. from Mbeya. She is married with four children between the ages of 3 and 11. Tegemea has been running a Vitenge business since 2008. She has established a store that sells traditional clothing worn by Tanzanian women, called kanga and vitenge. The kanga is a piece of printed cotton fabric often with a border along all four sides. It is printed using the silkscreen method with its pattern in frames. Kitenge (the Swahili plural is vitenge) is a cotton fabric with wax print, printed by using rotary printing machines. Kitenge is a communicating textile - the various colors, patterns, writings and symbols represent moods, feelings, cultures, and traditions of native African people. She works at her business for 12 hours per day, 7 days per week and is assisted by her husband. Tegemea currently earns about 350USD from her business. She is requesting a loan to purchase more vitenge in bulk. In the future, she plans to open the same business at another location. Tegemea thanks you for your support!


SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more vitenge in bulk

loans.name: Delia

texts.es:
La socia DELIA pertenece al banco comunal “VIRGEN ASUNTA, ella vive en el distrito de calca de la provincia de Urubamba del departamento del Cusco. La ciudad de Calca esta a una hora de la provincia de Cusco. 

La socia tiene 52 años de edad, es casada, tiene tres hijos. Ella tiene un pequeño negocio de producción y distribución de panes (Panadería). 

Ella alterna sus actividades del hogar con la elaboración de panes y venta de panes. Ella distribuye muy temprano en la mañana a las demás tiendas de la ciudad los panes con ayuda de un empleado. Ya tiene vaR. años con esta actividad y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone a su trabajo.  

La socia requiere el préstamo para aumentar el capital del negocio de producción y venta de panes, ella quiere comprar más insumos como harina, aceite, azúcar, etc. 

La socia se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Delia is a member of the "Virgen Asunta" community bank. She live is the district of Calca, province of Urubamba, department of Cusco. The city of Calca is is one hour from the province of Cusco. This member is 52-years-old, married, and has three children. She has a small business for baking and selling breads (known as a "panadería"). Delia alternates her duties at home with the making and selling of bread. Very early in the morning, she distributes bread to other stores across the city with the help of an employee. She has been in this business for a few years, and it has gone very well thanks to all of the effort that she puts into her job. This member requires a loan to be able to increase her working capital for bread production and sales. She would like to buy more ingredients such as flour, oil, sugar, etc. Delia is thankful for the opportunity that this lending method provides, and likewise she agrees to meet her payments according to the schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Merchlewitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy more ingredients like flour, oil, sugar, etc. for making bread

loans.name: Adam

texts.en:
Adam is 31 years old and has a Jua Kali (informal) business in the market selling boxes, pots, jikos (stoves), and buckets. He usually sells to parents of school children and other passersby. He's been in this business for twelve years and also earns some income from small-scale farming. He describes himself as hardworking and innovative.

Adam requested this loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings from Faulu in order to expand his business by purchasing materials. He says that this loan will enable him to earn a sustainable income for his family. In the future, he hopes to become an employer to create opportunities for others.

loans.use: To buy more products to sell

loans.name: Nguyễn's Group

texts.en:
H. Nguyễn Thị is a 35 year-old female living in the town of Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  H. is the group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by SEDA.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Trác Bút 1 - nhóm 01.


H. is married and has 2 school-aged children.  To making a living, H. owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting fruits & vegetables for sale.  H. has been engaged in this business for over 7 years and earns approximately 3.600.000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2007, H. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  H. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4.256.000 VND from SEDA.  This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure.  She is now requesting a new  loan of 4.256.000 VND which will be used to purchase general farm supplies & equipment.  The loan will be the 4th loan she has taken out with SEDA.  H. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support extended members of her family.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  Mẫn Thị N. is a 33 year-old female who is requesting a 2.912.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


2.  Nguyễn Thị Hà is a 30 year-old female who is requesting a 672.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase general farm supplies & equipment

loans.name: Eugenia

texts.en:
Eugenia L. is from the city of San Fermin, Cauayan, Isabela. She is 39 years old. Eugenia is married and has 4 school-aged children. Eugenia owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling clothing products in the local community. Eugenia has been involved in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Eugenia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eugenia is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Eugenia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Gunkeshari

texts.en:
Gun Keshari M. lives in a single family dwelling with her husband and two sons. She lives in Thecho, in the Lalitpur district. Thecho is famous for vegetable farming. Her older son makes traditional idols and her younger son is studying in grade 7. Her husband, Mr. Santa Lal M. is a carpenter.

Mrs. M. opened her tailoring shop 6 years ago. Her specialty is making ladies dresses. She prefers to make popular dresses like Kurta Sulwar, blouses, ladies long dresses, Makhshi, and other items. Before starting her own business, Mrs. M. took a 4-month training course in tailoring. With her first loan she was able to purchase clothes and equipment for her work.

Now she needs Rs30,000 to buy supplies for her tailoring work.

loans.use: to buys supplies for her tailoring work

loans.name: Visitacion's Group

texts.en:
Visitacion S. is from the town of Santo Domingo Echague. She is 30 years old. Visitacion is the leader of a 9-member loan group sponsored by ASKI. Although each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for repaying the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Visitacion is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Visitacion prepares and sells cooked food for daily meals. Visitacion has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Visitacion joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Visitacion is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Visitacion's first loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
Dolores A. has three children. Before receiving a loan, she said, it was really hard because she could not easily pay the price demanded for the farm supplies that she needs. Dolores wishes to have a productive farm so that she can help her husband pay the daily expenses in their home.

Dolores has requested a loan of 15,000 PHP from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies to increase her harvest.

loans.use: to buy farm supplies

loans.name: Donata

texts.es:
Donata es socia del Banco Comunal Laureles.
Donata es soltera, tiene 29 años y 2 hijos, Donata tiene un puesto en el mercado Nery en donde vende verduras, camote, actividad que realiza todos los días.
Donata necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de camote y zanahoria.
Los sueños de Donata son ampliar su negocio y brindar una buena educación a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Donata is a member of the Laurales communal bank. She is the 29 year old mother of two children. She has a spot in the Nery market, where she sells vegetables and sweet potatoes daily. She needs a loan of 1,000 PEN to ($375) to buy sweet potatoes and carrots. She hopes to be able to expand her business and provide a good educational opportunity for her children.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in sweet potatoes and carrots

loans.name: Edgar

texts.es:
Edgar C. L. tiene 57 años y vive en el barrio Nuevo Chile de Bogotá, donde tiene una tienda en la cual comercializa víveres; este hombre casado y con cinco hijos está solicitando un crédito por valor de $1.000.000 para comprar mercancías como dulces y víveres en general y venderlos en su tienda ubicada en su propia casa. Desde hace dos años que se vinculó al proyecto Raíces Nuevas, convenio realizado con la Unión Europea, la Secretaría  de Gobierno distrital, la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo y el SENA, que generó alternativas emprendedoras   a desplazados ubicados en sectores marginales de Bogotá y   a través del fondo rotatorio de este programa, Edgar pudo acceder a crédito  y hacer real su emprendimiento.
Con su primer crédito pudo comprar canastas de refrescos, que lo ayudaron a aumentar sus ingresos y dirigirlos al bienestar de su familia, que aunque fueron  desplazados de una población del Tolima hace 6 años, lograron con mucho esfuerzo, iniciar su nueva vida en Bogotá la capital de Colombia, pero han conseguido muchas amistades, pues en  el sector donde viven es usual  que se realicen eventos de integración como campeonatos de futbol entre diversos sectores y esto ha ayudado a mucho a el ya su familia.

loans.use: comprar mercancías como dulces y víveres en general

loans.name: God Fearing People Group

texts.en:
James V. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called God Fearing People. He is 49 years old and single, with 6 children who range from 8 to 17 years old. He also cares for a sibling. James could not continue his education through college.

For 20 years James has been selling slippers at the Redlight market in Paynesville, Liberia. He sells his slippers at low prices and sells slippers that customers need in order to encourage them to continue patronizing his business.

James started selling with very little cash. He plans to use his 6,000 LRD portion of this 30,000 LRD group loan to buy more slippers to improve his business. His goal is to grow and expand his business and to improve his family's living conditions. In the photo that accompanies this profile, James is the one holding the sign. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more slippers to improve his business

loans.name: Vicenta

texts.es: Vicenta R. reside en el departamento de La Unión, vive junto a su hija y dos nietos de 4 y 5 años de edad. A sus 63 años de edad, Vicenta trabaja día con día comerciando ropa para mujeres, la cual vende por los diferentes cantones y caseríos cercanos a La Unión, incluso ella prefiere caminar largos trayectos para llegar a lugares muy remotos, en los cuales a pesar del enorme cansancio y esfuerzo, los prefiere ya que son pocas las ventas que existen en esas zonas, en donde muchas personas la esperan para poder adquirir sus productos. Vicenta solicita un préstamo para poder invertir en su negocio, de manera que pueda comprar mayor cantidad de ropa y de esta forma obtenerla a precios más bajos lo cual le permite vender más barato y así obtener nuevos clientes. A pesar de su edad Vicenta se esfuerza día con día para poder obtener el sustento diario y así mismo para todos sus gastos personales.
texts.en:
Vicenta R. lives in the Department of La Union with her daughter and two grandchildren, ages 4 and 5. At 63, Vicenta is still working every day. Her trade is women’s clothing, which she sells in the communities and villages near La Union. She prefers walking to remote areas. To her, it’s worth the effort and fatigue; few people sell clothing in these places, so there are plenty of potential customers. Vicenta has requested a loan so that she can invest in her business by buying more clothing. If she buys more at once, she’ll be able to pay a lower price, sell for less, and earn more new customers. Despite her age, Vicenta works every day to earn a living and keep up with her personal expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Corinne Gilroy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying clothing.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Buying manure and farm supplies and renting a tractor for plowing

loans.name: Helida

texts.en:
Helida T is currently in the business of selling various items in the shop such as bags of salt, biscuits, etc., and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of sugar and boxes of soap to sell. Helida is 43 years old and is married with a husband that is a peasant. She has 6 children, and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of sugar and boxes of soap to sell

loans.name: Lesbia Verónica

texts.es:
La Sra. V. M.  es una profesora  que trabaja en una Esc. Ubicada en el municipio del Viejo donde a la vez habita.

Ella va a utilizar el crédito para reparar el techo de su casa ya  que según ella cada vez que llueve, toda el agua se les pasas por medio del zinc y sus niños se le están enfermando 

La Sra. V. M.  es madre de 3 niños los cuales ella sirve de padre y madre para ellos ya que su padre no vive con ellos, pero con la ayuda de Dios y su trabajo ha podido darles la educación necesaria a sus hijos, nos dijo la Sra. 

Este es el primer crédito que ha Sra. Tiene con la Institución, a lo cual dice estar muy agradecida por la oportunidad que le han otorgado y espera seguir trabajando con CEPRODEL.
texts.en:
Ms. V. M. is a teacher at a school located in the city of Viejo where she currently lives. She is going to use the loan to repair her roof as every time it rains, the water leaks through the zinc sheet metal and her children are getting sick. Ms. V. M. is both mother and father to her 3 children as their father does not live with them. She tells us that with the help of God and by working, she has been able to provide her children with the education they need. This is her first loan with the institution. She is grateful for the opportunity that she has been given and hopes to continue working with CEPRODEL.

Translated from Spanish by Eleanor Francoletti-Putz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Home improvement and repair

loans.name: Artemio

texts.es:
El señor Artemio C. le esta agradecido por su cooperación en el anterior crédito el cual su negocio a crecido mas. 
Esta nuevamente solicitando su cooperación para este nuevo préstamo ya que le esta haciendo falta mas inventario y desea tener mas variedad de alimentos para vender, pero no cuenta con el capital necesarios para la inserción es por eso que esta solicitando un préstamo y así invertir en el negocio ya que es la fuente de ingresos de su familia.
Planea pagar el crédito con las ganancias que obtiene del negocio.
texts.en:
Artemio C. is grateful for the cooperation in his previous loan, with which his business has grown. He is again seeking your cooperation for this new loan since he is short on inventory and wishes to offer more variety of foods to sell. But he does not have the necessary capital to invest and for this reason he is seeking this loan to invest in his business and increase his family's income. He plans to repay the loan with the earnings from his business.

Translated from Spanish by Michelle Harrison, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investment in his business

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James was born in 1977 and is single. He takes care of one dependent. James owns a small business selling various products such as cosmetics and supplies which are used for bread. This business is fruitful in his community. James has two years of experience in his business. The hours of his shop are from 6 in the morning to 9 in the evening every day except on Saturday.

James is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand his business by purchasing more new products and offering another service like a public phone. Increasing his products will allow him to satisfy all the customers who are living near his residence. In so doing, James will be able to earn more profits.

loans.use: To expanding his business

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 22-year-old single man from Lebanon. He lives with his parents and three siblings, two of whom are still unemployed. In order to help with his family’s expenses, he has opened a barber shop near to his home. The business has been established since 2007 and he has six years of experience in this occupation. Despite his young age, the borrower is very supportive of his father, who works as a farmer, and he helps him with the household expenses. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. so as to be able to expand his business by adding new services and purchasing more equipment. He will also be able to attract new clients. Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (e.g. blanking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.). Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers. About Ameen: Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese micro-finance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in micro-finance. At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes. Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loan from Kiva to offer lower interest loans with faster disbursement to its micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling US$115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please click here.

loans.use: To add new services and purchase more equipment

loans.name: Real Atahuallpa Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal “Real Atahuallpa” actualmente se encuentra en el XII ciclo y está conformado por personas trabajadoras y emprendedoras que buscan a cada momento las oportunidades para salir adelante y con su esfuerzo diario entregar un mejor futuro a sus hijos. Las reuniones del banco comunal son cada treinta días en la oficina central de la Institución de Micro finanzas Arariwa que está ubicado en el distrito de Wanchaq provincia del Cusco. La mayoría de los socios se dedican al comercio.  

Mónica nació  en la ciudad de Cusco y tiene 33 años, Actualmente, Mónica vive en la misma ciudad donde nació junto con su esposo sus dos hijos. Antes, Mónica vendía ceviche de forma ambulatoria en la esquina de la calle Dolorospata del distrito de Santiago pero como hay mucha contaminación por la zona cerró el negocio.   

Decidido a empezar una nueva vida, Mónica utilizo sus ahorros para abrir una pequeña tienda de abarrotes, donde vende arroz, azúcar y muchas cosas más. Le pueden encontrar todos 7 días de la semana, desde las 6 de la mañana hasta las 8 de la noche. 

Con su próximo préstamo, Mónica que espera recibir S/. 300 nuevos soles. Por el momento, su tienda esta modestamente equipado con las necesidades básicas. Le gustaría emplear el dinero del préstamo para comprar tarjetas de llamadas. El anhelo del socio es abrir una tienda más grande o tener una cebichería. Mónica es una de los socias fundadores del banco comunal y es una persona puntual y responsable.
texts.en:
The communal bank "Real Atahuallpa" is now in its 12th loan cycle. It is made up of hardworking and enterprising people who are always on the lookout for opportunities to get ahead, and who make a daily effort to provide a better future for their children. The group meets every 30 days in the central offices of the Institución de Micro finanzas Arariwa, which is located in the Wanchaq district of Cusco province. The majority of the members work in retail trade. Monica, 33, was born in the city of Cusco. She now lives in the city where she was born with her husband and their 2 children. Before, Monica used to work as a street vendor selling ceviche on the corner of Dolorospata street in the Santiago district, but as there is a lot of pollution in the area she closed that business. Determined to start a new life, Monica used her savings to open a small grocery store where she sells rice, sugar and many other items. There you can find her every day of the week, from 6 in the morning until 8 at night. With her next loan, Monica hopes to receive 300 Peruvian soles. Right now, her store is modestly supplied with the basic necessities. Monica would like to use the money from the loan to buy calling cards. She would like to open a store that is bigger, or have a seafood restaurant. Monica is one of the founding members of the communal bank, and she is a person who is responsible and punctual.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy calling cards

loans.name: Amethyst

texts.en: Amethyst P. is from the village of Poblacion III. She is 36 years old and is married with four infant children. Amethyst owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Amethyst joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mabinty

texts.en:
Mabinty K. is 35 years old. She is married and has five children, aged 17, 15 and 12 years. All of her children are secondary-school pupils. 

Mabinty started her business in the year 1991. For the past years, she has been selling clothing such as jeans, men’s shirts and gara (dyed clothing). Her business is located in the Cotton Tree Market in Makeni. 

Mabinty started this business to be able to generate enough profit to help her husband provide a livelihood for their family. Mabinty works seven days a week and 11 hours daily. On average, Mabinty earns 900,000 Sierra Leone leones (SLL) monthly from her business.

Mabinty has a very good loan repayment history. She needs a loan of 3,000,000SLL to help her buy ready-made jeans and men's shirts for her business. She intends to use the proceeds from this loan to educate her children and buy a piece of land. She thanks you for supporting her.

loans.use: To buy ready-made shirts and jeans

loans.name: Clarita

texts.en:
Clarita M. is from the village of Poblacion, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is 54 years old. Clarita is single and has one adult-aged child. To make a living, Clarita owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector, operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Clarita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Clarita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Clarita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Clarita is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Clarita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Catalino Facundo

texts.es:
El productor Catalino Facundo habita en la colonia Providencia del municipio de Nueva Guinea junto a su familia compuesta por su esposa Carmen Guzman, y sus hijos Marvin y Daysi, quienes le ayudan a las actividades de la finca. 

Esta solicitando 2do crédito para establecer pasto mejorado, lo que le permitiria comercializar y brindarle mejor cuido a su hato ganadero, pues así aseguraria la alimentación del ganado en tiempo de sequía, ya que mantendria su hato ganadero en buen desarrollo y le permitiria que obtengan un peso necesario a corto plazo. 

Don Catalino ademas establece cultivos de raices y tuberculos, se ha destacado por su gran responsabilidad en sus compromisos crediticios, trabajador, y honesto.
texts.en:
The producer Catalino Facundo lives in the Providence district of the New Guinea municipality. He lives together with his family, made up of his wife, Carmen Guzman, and their children Marvin and Daysi, who help them with farm work. 

He is asking for his 2nd loan to establish better grass, which will permit him to commercialize and to allow him to better care for his herd of livestock. In this way he could assure that the livestock would have food in times of draught. In this way he would maintain the herd in good development and it would allow the animals to maintain a necessary weight over the short term. Mr. Catalino is also establishing crops of roots and tubers. 

He has stood out for his responsibility in his loan repayments, his hard work, and his honesty.

loans.use: To plant grass

loans.name: Adela

texts.en: Adela E. is a married woman who lives in Purok Narra, Barangay Tinampaan, Cadiz City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: a tailoring business and a sari-sari (general) store. Her husband Jose, who is 58 years old, works as a driver to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have four children who are 13 to 28 years old. Adela joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 17 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Adela has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 15,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of about $94, thus raising the family's standard of living. This time, for her 10th cycle loan, she is borrowing 17,000 PHP, which she intends to use to purchase raw materials so that she can continue to save up for the future and to put up her own tailoring shop. Adela E. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials for tailoring

loans.name: Zhora

texts.en: Zhora V. is married and has one child.  He is engaged in cattle farming.  Zhora has room facilities and cattle food to expand his farm. The family will be growing, and Zhora would like to insure a sufficient income for them. He has applied for a loan to increase the livestock.

loans.use: To increase the livestock

loans.name: Komi

texts.fr: Il est  marié et  âgé de 36 ans.  IL a en charge 2 enfants.  Pour pouvoir s’occuper de ses enfants, il fait la vente de matériel électronique. Il a démarré en 2009 ses activités et achète ses matériels au grand marché de Lomé.  Il revend  ensuite vendre ses matériels dans une boutique sise à Bèkpota à côté de l’hôtel Bijou.  Avec le nouveau, il espère acheter  12 cartons d’ampoule, 2 cartons de câbles VGV et 5 compteurs.
texts.en: This 36-year-old married man has two children in his care. In  order to provide for his children, he sells electronic equipment. He started this activity in 2009, and gets his supplies at the main market in Lomé. The merchandise is then sold in a store located next to the Bijou hotel, in Bèkpota. With the new loan, he plans to buy 12 boxes of bulbs, 2 boxes of VGV cables and 5 meters.

loans.use: Purchase of electrical equipment

loans.name: Fredrick

texts.en:
Fredrick is 57 years old and married with seven adult children. For the past 25 years, he has been in the farming business. Fredrick’s farm is located in Kisii town, western Kenya, where he produces beans, maize and tea to sell at the local market and through the Kenya Tea Development Authority. He depends on the income from his farm to provide for the basic needs of his family.

Fredrick is requesting a loan of 45,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that his family will be assured of enough milk for both domestic consumption and sale. The profits from this loan will help improve Fredrick’s farm. In the future, he plans to acquire more dairy cows and expand his milk production.

loans.use: to purchase a cow

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 52-year-old married man living with his wife and three young children. He is from Lebanon. He has specialized in baking bread and pastries for 20 years and in 2000, he decided to open a small bakery. Despite his old age, he is doing big efforts to proceed with his work to handle his family’s expenses. He has obtained his first Kiva loan and he was a very good client with payments on time. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to increase his inventory to produce more and, as a result, get higher profits.

loans.use: To increase his inventory

loans.name: Mireya Adriana

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Estrella De Belén que se reúne cada 15 días en el Barrio Santa Marianita de la ciudad de  Manta, conocido por sus hermosas playas que son muy visitadas en toda época del año por turistas nacionales y extranjeros, en  este lugar la mayoría de los habitantes se dedica a la pesca y a las faenas del mar.

En este lugar encontramos a la señora Mireya, tiene 21 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre desde hace seis meses, aun no tiene hijos pero muy pronto va a tener su primer hijo. El marido se dedica a la pesca.
 
Ella tiene un negocio de venta de materiales de pesca como por ejemplo redes, anzuelos, piolas entre  otras muchas cosas que se requieren para realizar una buena pesca en alta mar, trabaja tres días a la semana y su forma de venta es ofreciendo sus productos a los pescadores una vez que llegan de alta mar, ella cada quince días viaja hasta el centro de Manta a comprar lo necesario para que cuando lleguen sus clientes tener de todo, nos cuenta que viene realizando esta actividad ya por dos años y que le ha oído muy bien.

Este crédito es para comprar redes, piolas, anzuelos, grapas, entre otros. Está en el Banco Comunal desde hace 4 ciclos y le gusta porque sus compañeras son muy ordenadas. Sus sueños son terminar sus estudios y seguir adelante.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank “Estrella De Belén” (Star of Bethlehem) meets every fifteen days in the neighborhood of Santa Marianita in the city of Manta. This place is known for its beautiful beaches that are visited year round by foreign and domestic tourists. Most of the residents engage in fishing or other jobs related to the sea.

This is where one can find Sra. Mireya. She is 21 years old and has been in a common law relationship for six months. At the moment, she does not have any children but is expecting her first child very shortly. Her husband works as a fisherman.

Mireya has a business selling fishing equipment such as nets, hooks, lanyards, and other items required to conduct fishing on the high seas. She works three days per week and offers her merchandise to the fishermen when they arrive at the port. Every fifteen days, Mireya travels to central Manta to buy what she needs so that she will have everything when her customers arrive. She says that she has been in this business for two years and has done very well.

The loan will be used to buy nets, ropes, hooks, cable clips, and other items. She has been with the Communal Bank for four loan cycles and enjoys the fact that her fellow members have been orderly. Her dreams include finishing her studies and continuing to move forward.

loans.use: Purchase nets, ropes, hooks, cable clips, and other pieces of fishing equipment

loans.name: Hilary

texts.en:
Hilary A. is a 27-year-old, married man from the town of Bunawan. Hilary and his wife have two children, who are 1 and 2 years old. To earn a living, Hilary owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector. More specifically, his primary source of income is derived from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Hilary works hard to support his family and to save for his children's future.

Hilary joined CEVI to gain access to financial services, which in turn improves both his ability to engage in business activities and his family's standard of living. Notably, Hilary has already successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Hilary is now requesting another loan, this time in the amount of 11,000 PHP ($275), which will be used to purchase seeds and fertilizers.

loans.use: To expand and improve his business by purchasing seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 20-year-old single woman from Lebanon. She lives with her parents and four siblings. She has been running a clothing store since 2009. She also sells accessories from her store. Her business income is vital to support her family. 

Today, she is requesting a loan of $1200 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to expand her store’s inventory. She says that the loan will help her diversify her merchandise selection. In the future, she is hoping to also sell shoes from her store. Currently, she mostly sells clothes.

loans.use: To expand her store’s inventory

loans.name: Feni

texts.en:
Feni is a married woman with five children, all of whom attend school. Her husband is a security agent; he contributes to his family basic needs with his earnings. They own a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

Feni has operated a food stall for the past three years, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She dreams of expanding her business and becoming self-reliant in the future. 

She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. With the 15,000 KES loan, she wants to purchase wheat flour, beans, cooking oil, salt, and utensils for her food stall.

loans.use: To purchase wheat flour, beans, cooking oil, salt and utensils for her food stall.

loans.name: Vicsia Maria

texts.es: Vicsia Maria tiene su negocio que es la venta de comida. Hace más de 16 años que tiene este negocio, por lo que no es la primera vez que solicita este crédito. Ella inicio vendiendo en su vivienda, pues la mayoría de sus clientes saben que ella ofrece unos deliciosos platillos, ha demostrado ser una persona responsable y disfruta de su actividad. El financiamiento que solicita es para la compra de granos básicos, bolsas, platos, vasos, verduras entre otros productos necesarios. Su deseo es acondicionar su negocio y surtirlos con mucho productos solicitados por la comunidad y con los que muchas veces no tiene en existencia, así mismo trabajará mucho con su cónyuge, para lograr la meta de educar a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Vicsia María’s business is selling food.  She’s had the business for over 16 years so this isn’t her first loan request.  

She started out selling from home because the majority of her customers know that she offers delicious dishes.  She has shown herself to be a responsible persona and she enjoys her activity.

The requested loan is to buy basic grains, bags, plates, glasses and vegetables, among other necessary products.  Her wish is to equip her business and stock it with lots of the products requested by the community and which she sometimes does not have available.  She will also work hard with her spouse to reach the goal of educating their children.

loans.use: to buy basic grains, bags, plates, glasses and vegetables, among other necessary products

loans.name: Yaqueline

texts.es:
La señora Yaqueline es una mujer y madre muy joven que esta dispuesta a salir adelante ante las adversidades, hace tiempo se separo de su esposo por lo que tuvo que mantener sola a sus dos pequeños. 
En este momento se ve en la necesidad de solicitar un préstamo para pagar las escrituras de su vivienda, de tal manera tendrá todo en orden para un futuro que sus hijos crezcan y puedan tener su propio patrimonio.
texts.en:
Yaqueline is a young mother who is determined to get ahead through her activities.  She separated from her husband some time ago and has had to support her two children on her own.

At this time she has seen fit to request a loan to pay for her home’s deed, which will allow her to put everything in order for a future where her children will be able to grow up and have a heritage all their own.

loans.use: to pay for a deed

loans.name: C4824 Tunezeranwe Group

texts.en:
Beathe is 26 years old with one child who is 2 years old..She is pictured above on the right. For three years, she has owned a small shop which sells various products such as rice, sugar, cosmetics, and so on. Her business is open from 6 am until 7 pm every day. Beathe and her business are well known in the region, which is the reason why she is the leader of the group called “Tunezeranwe” in the local language. Her group consists of two women and three men.

Beathe and her group have requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more products like rice, sugar, cosmetics, and so on for their businesses. Beathe especially needs this loan in order to expand her product offering and to satisfy the demands of her customers. If this satisfaction is reached, Beathe and the other group members hope to earn more profits. With these profits, she expects to save money for her future and to pay her children’s school fees.

loans.use: to purchase more product to sell like rice ,sugar, and beans.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a married woman with three sons, 2 had graduated from school while 1 is still attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, rent, and clothing. 

For the past eight years, she has been operating a restaurant business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business.  Mary dreams of owning her own land in the future.

With this loan for Kshs 20,000, Mary wants to purchase wheat flour, maize flour and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase wheat flour, maize flour and cooking oil for her restaurant

loans.name: Rajabu

texts.en:
Rajabu is married to a business woman and has 2 children, both of whom attend school.  They live in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are rent and school fees. 

For the past 4 years, Rajabu has been operating a medical clinic business.  His potential customers are neighbours and passersby. He faces a major challenge of seasonality in his business.  Rajabu dreams of owning a business premise in the future.

With this loan for Kshs 20,000, Rajabu wants to purchase a scale to weigh infants and adults. He decided to join Yehu because of its good customer relations.

loans.use: buy a weighing machine

loans.name: Eddy Vidal

texts.es:
Eddy Vidal tiene 30 años, vive en Union Libre vive con la compañera y con los hijos. Vive en El Cantón Ventanas Provincia de Los Ríos.

Esta Ventanilla se llama NUEVO HORIZONTE, se encuentra ubicada en el Recinto Cachely Grande, perteneciente al cantón Ventanas, esta ventanilla se dedica a labores agrícolas de ciclo corto siembra de maíz, arroz, frejol gandul.

Eddy se dedica a la agricultura en especial a la siembra de maíz, arroz y frejol, las compras las realiza en Comercial "Hnos. Olivos" cada mes y las vende en la feria de la misma localidad.

Solicita el crédito para la compra de semillas y abonos para los cultivos.  Con el apoyo del crédito le ayudaría económicamente para suplir sus necesidades. Enfrentar desafíos como enfermedades en los cultivos y la falta de terreno propio. Su sueño es comprar un terreno.

Le gusta jugar indor.
texts.en:
Eddy Vidal is 30 years old.  He lives with his partner and children in Ventanas canton, in Los Ríos province.

This community bank is called "Nuevo Horizonte" (New Horizon).  It is located in Cachely Grande, in Ventanas canton.  The members of this group work in short-cycle agriculture, growing corn, rice and pigeon peas.

Eddy grows crops, especially corn, rice and beans.  He makes his purchases in "Hnos. Olivos" store each month and makes his sales in the street market in the same town.

Eddy is requesting this loan to buy seeds and fertilizers for his crops.  The support of this loan will help him to financially cover his needs.  He faces challenges in his work such as crop diseases and the fact that he doesn't own his own land.  His dream is to buy a plot of land.

Eddy enjoys playing indoor soccer.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizers for his crops

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia is 57 years old and lives in Fatima, Liloy, Zamboanga del Norte. She is single.
Patricia has a boarding house business and earns approximately 10000 each month doing this type of work. She has requested a loan of 50,000 to purchase material for her boarding house.
Patricia has been a member of PMPC for just this year. In the future, Patricia hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase material for her boarding house

loans.name: Tohir

texts.en:
Tohir is a very responsible and optimistic person and he has two children and a wife to support. Tohir wishes to develop his business. This business consists of cattle-raising in his village because there is a very high demand for milk from villagers and especially from customers who come from enclosed towns. Tohir is helped by his wife. He is currently faced with many problems because his children are growing and, accordingly, their expenses are growing too. The only way to get out of this difficulty is to succeed in business, so we hope that the capabilities and services provided by IMON International will help him improve the business.  

 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to purchase more small cattle

loans.name: Magda Margot

texts.es:
(Quillabamba es la ciudad capital de Provincia de La Convención e importante centro de comercio de las valles de Lares y La Convención, las actividades principales son la producción de coca, café, cacao y frutales).
En la ciudad de Quillabamba visitamos al banco comunal “Los Corazones Valientes de Morro San Juan” y conocimos a la socia Margot y nos cuenta: 

 “Nací en la ciudad de Quillabamba, tengo 26 años edad, tengo un hijo y vivo en la misma ciudad donde nací y mi actividad principal es la crianza de animales menores”. 

Margot es una mujer luchadora y emprendedora que a pesar de las adversidades trabaja en la crianza de animales menores como por ejemplo pollos, ella compra pollitos y los alimenta con nutrientes y suplementos después de hacerlo engordar los vende en la ciudad de Quillabamba. En esta oportunidad requiere el préstamo para comprar alimento para los pollos.
texts.en:
